pullRequest.body:
Try to call a local install of Singular (either standalone or inside Sage) to find the witness for polyrith before trying to call the online sage cell server.

---

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [75ad47415d](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20334/commits/75ad47415d0157c161cd22461cc3ba4dd2535819)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ create_macaulay2_query`
`+ create_singular_query(type:`
`+ evaluate_in_macaulay2(query:`
`+ evaluate_in_singular(query:`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

@miguelmarco Thank you for your work and I personally think supporting a local install is important. This PR is already pretty large for review. I think a better way is to make a refactoring pull request first for adding an attribute `@[polyrith_backend]`, and tag the current function `runSage` that calls Sage over an internet API with it. (There are alternative ways like using something similar to `register_hint`; I can help with this part)

Then in a second PR or downstream project, support a local Sage install by tagging a suitable function with `@[polyrith_backend]`. If you want to support other systems, we can discuss whether to make further PRs that support them. I think users should be able to choose which backend to use by setting some suitable options.

I don't really like the idea of writing the same script twice in entirely different languages, and having to support both. 

Can we either invoke a local sage installation, or get the safe server to run a singular script?

I guess so, it seems that the sage cell server has a field to specify the language you want to use.

However, I was thinking on the contrary: support as many local CAS as we can (I started looking on how the Macaulay2 script should be), so Lean will use whatever CAS is locally installed.

I just added support for Macaulay2. I will try to add also support for CoCoA. 

Right now, I don't have access to proprietary systems like Magnma, Mathematica or Maple, so I will not be able to work on them for the moment. I took a quick look at how Maxima and Sympy handle Grbner Basis, and their support is limited compared to the previous ones; so it might be harder to implement this functionality on top of them.

> Right now, I don't have access to proprietary systems like Magnma, Mathematica or Maple, so I will not be able to work on them for the moment.

Every one of these contributed to Mathlib becomes a maintenance burden, as people without access to these systems will then not be able to test changes to their code.

I think mathlib should only support external solvers that we are able to run in CI. If we can't test the code in CI, then it become a liability and should probably live outside mathlib itself. I could envisage an extension mechanism of some kind that lets downstream libraries register additional solvers with polyrith.

I see, an extension mechanism would definitely be nice.

About the CI issue, I guess adding Singular and/or Macaulay2 to the Dockerfile could make sense (and that way, we get to actually test polyrith in CI in a deterministic way). Sage is so big that it would be probably overkill.
Any idea on how to implement an extension mechanism? or how to proceed meanwhile?

How about:
* come up with a nice signature for a polyrith provider function
* (in Mathlib) write an attribute like `@[polyrith_backend]`, and add that to the Mathlib function that calls Sage over the network
* (in Mathlib) have the polyrith tactic look up the most recent declaration (or better, allow the attribute to have a priority) with `@[polyrith_backend]` and call that
* in a downstream project provide a lakefile that pulls in a containerized Sage (with CI testing!), and provides an alternative `@[polyrith_backend]` function

Then user requiring the downstream project and importing the file with the new attribute should get local Sage execution.
Thanks. Since that involves a deep redesign of the polyrith tactic, maybe it will be better to consider both this an #17626 at the same time.

> How about:
> 
>     * come up with a nice signature for a polyrith provider function
> 
>     * (in Mathlib) write an attribute like `@[polyrith_backend]`, and add that to the Mathlib function that calls Sage over the network
> 
>     * (in Mathlib) have the polyrith tactic look up the most recent declaration (or better, allow the attribute to have a priority) with `@[polyrith_backend]` and call that
> 
>     * in a downstream project provide a lakefile that pulls in a containerized Sage (with CI testing!), and provides an alternative `@[polyrith_backend]` function
> 
> 
> Then user requiring the downstream project and importing the file with the new attribute should get local Sage execution.

So you think we should stick to Sage only, instead of trying to support more CAS systems?

Personally I think it makes sense to target a lighter system such as Singular. Sage is a huge Behemoth, and it is probably overkill to ask people to install it if they just want to use polyrith without requiring an internet connection.

> come up with a nice signature for a polyrith provider function

I think a reasonable signature is

```
def runSage (trace : Bool) ( : Expr) (atoms : Nat) (hyps : Array (Source  Poly)) (target : Poly) :
    CoreM SageResult
```

found in the newest `Polyrith.lean` after #17626 (here `SageResult` is `Except SageError SageSuccess` where `SageError` can contain an error message, and `SageSuccess` is either the final result of coefficients for local hypotheses and the `exp` parameter for `linear_combination`, or some log for debugging).

pullRequest.title: feat: allow polyrith to use a local Singular/Sage install

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(Tactic/Polyrith): remove polyrith dependency on Python
